required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Effectiveness and Tolerability of Lidocaine 5% Spray in Treatment of Lifelong Premature Ejaculation Patients.
clinical_study.official_title: Effectiveness and Tolerability of Lidocaine 5% Spray in Treatment of Lifelong Premature Ejaculation Patients. A Randomized Single-blind Placebo-controlled Clinical Trial.

brief_summary.textblock: This study aimed to appraise effectiveness and tolerability of lidocaine 5% spray in treatment of patients with premature ejaculation (PE). The current study has been designed as a randomized single-blind placebo-controlled clinical trial. It was done on 150 lifelong PE patients with normal erection. They were randomized evenly categorized into two treatment groups. Group 1 (n₌75); was given on demand lidocaine 5% spray for 8 weeks. Group 2 (n₌75); was given placebo in form on demand alcohol spray for 8 weeks.

detailed_description.textblock: This study aimed to appraise effectiveness and tolerability of lidocaine 5% spray in treatment of patients with premature ejaculation (PE). The current study has been designed as a randomized single-blind placebo-controlled clinical trial. It was done on 150 lifelong PE patients with normal erection. They were randomized evenly categorized into two treatment groups. Group 1 (n₌75); was given on demand lidocaine 5% spray for 8 weeks. Group 2 (n₌75); was given placebo in form on demand alcohol spray for 8 weeks. All medications were applied on the glans penis for 10-20 minutes and then cleaned before planed sexual intercourse. Patients were evaluated with Arabic Index of Premature Ejaculation (AIPE) scores, intravaginal ejaculatory latency times (IELTs), and frequency of sexual intercourse before and after treatments.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Group 1 (n₌75); was given on demand lidocaine 5% spray for 8 weeks (One to two applications (1-2 ml) of lidocaine 5% sprays; contain 5 -10 mg of lidocaine, in a metered dose aerosol-delivery system). Group 2 (n₌75); was given placebo in form on demand alcohol spray for 8 weeks (One to two applications (1-2 ml) of alcohol 70% sprays).
study_design_info.masking_description: Patients were randomized evenly categorized into two treatment groups. Patient's distribution in the two groups was according to randomized encoded ballots, and they were unobservant of the type of the topical medications used.

primary_outcome.measure: Arabic Index of Premature Ejaculation Scores
primary_outcome.description: Patients were informed to fulfill the questionnaires of Arabic Index of Premature Ejaculation (AIPE).
Patients were informed to sign up intravaginal ejaculatory latency times (IELTs) using stopwatches.

arm_group.description: Group 1 (n₌75); was given on demand lidocaine 5% spray for 8 weeks (One to two applications (1-2 ml) of lidocaine 5% sprays; contain 5 -10 mg of lidocaine, in a metered dose aerosol-delivery system).
Group 2 (n₌75); was given placebo in form on demand alcohol spray for 8 weeks (One to two applications (1-2 ml) of alcohol 70% sprays).

intervention.description: Group 1 (n₌75); was given on demand lidocaine 5% spray for 8 weeks (One to two applications (1-2 ml) of lidocaine 5% sprays; contain 5 -10 mg of lidocaine, in a metered dose aerosol-delivery system).
Group 2 (n₌75); was given placebo in form on demand alcohol spray for 8 weeks.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
Clinical diagnosis of lifelong premature ejaculation
Exclusion Criteria:
1. renal or liver diseases,
2. diabetes mellitus,
3. thyroid diseases,
4. chronic prostatitis,
5. neurological diseases
6. allergic reactions to local anesthetics or alcohols.
7. erectil dysfunction

facility.name: Faculty of Medicine, Sohag University, Egypt

responsible_party.investigator_title: Assistant Professor of Dermatology, Venereology and Andrology Department, Faculty of Medicine, Sohag University, Egypt.
